title: Before 1 January 2018, will the UN Security Council hold an emergency meeting in response to new suspected use of chemical weapons in Syria?
preds: No one would benefit from it at this late stage.
The UN Security council will likely meet, but will not act, because Russia will veto any action against Assad.
Putin says the Syrians didn't use chemical weapons. Trump believes what Putin says. No impetus,, then, for SC meeting
GIven the current stalemate of situation in Syria, it is rather unlikely that the meeting will take place.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-chemicalweapons/syria-toxic-gas-inquiry-to-end-after-russia-again-blocks-u-n-renewal-idUSKBN1DH27L
Looks like all you have to do now is set your number to zero if you haven't already, and wait for it to be January.

probably reading too much into this... but if, as amnesty suggests, Syria has been given a green light,[1] the probability of that country's use of Chemical weapons may rise and thus the probability of an emergency meeting on the topic. I'm pretty sure it's easy to call an emergency meeting of the Security Council.  [1] http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-41740432
Seems easy to call/hold a meeting in response to emergency suspicions. Don't see why anyone would do it though.
Although unlikely, Assad may use chemical weapons to subdue last resistance. He may feel emboldened since world is not watching as closely.
They have loaded there weapons and will even strike us military when they get attacked from kim or china

I don't think Assad used chemical weapons in the last two accusations.  I think they were false flags. Assad had no upside to using chemical weapons, and we know Turkish troops found sarin gas in a Al Nusra camp, and UN inspectors verified that Assad had given up all his chemical weapons before the last attack. I think the last false flag was done to prompt Trump into doing something, but it didn't lead to anything, so there is no point.  Two failed attempts to get the US to invade. The US public doesn't want to go there.
I'm starting to believe that because the Syrian government is winning the war now, they don't need to deploy chemical weapons anymore.
At this point there's no upside for Assad to use chemical weapons.
Haven't heard much about Syrian chemical weapons lately.

Taking into account severe US & UN reactions to the last use in Idlib and the relative control that government forces now have with Russian backing. This reduces markedly the chance of the previous timeline of CW attacks continuing.
With the lack of media access and Russia's grip on controlling the region, even if Syria utilizes chemical weapons there would be few witnesses reporting it...
Dropping a little for passage of time.

In simple terms, both sides of the argument can plausibly deconstruct the other's allegations. From a Syrian and Russian perspective, they made the right choice in signing and complying with the chemical weapons convention, because they can plausibly deny responsibility for any future occurence of sarin, chlorine etc. — AND if they actually complied or abstained from the use, they have ALL the reasons to plausibly deny exactly such responsibility for any occurence of the material in the conflict zones, too.  From the current US/French perspective, the convenience (of sarin, chlorine and mustard gas) is a strong military temptation for the weak and desperate that the Syrian military cannot escape and its cooperation with the arms control inspectors was nothing but a “lavender marriage” that shows the ineffectiveness of Obama's Syria non-deterrence policy. http://carnegie-mec.org/diwan/68649 At least two organizations and France had been trying to establish the cause of deaths and injuries in Syria. Human Rights Watch argues that the Syrian air force would have used CWs on at least four occasions in the last eight months, citing witness reports and their own analysis of photographs, as well as citing rebuttals of Russian and Syrian versions of the stories. https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/05/01/syria-new-evidence-shows-pattern-nerve-agent-use The UN's arms control (OPCW), too, tried to analyse witness reports, photographs and videos. https://www.sipri.org/commentary/expert-comment/2017/g20-summit-and-chemical-weapons-syria The French are citing actual samples taken from the sites. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-intelligence-idUSKBN17S0RY There seems to be a heated debate about the linkage between the evidence of sarin and the Syrian government. For one side, it is plain and obvious, for the other a matter of fabrication. Given the alleged wide-spread use of CWs in the Syrian conflict, it might be reasonable to see further such reports and allegations in the next six months. However, the salience of the issue of chemical weapons in Syria was elevated multiple times by the US strike, by the G20 summit, by the release of “fact finding” mission reports etc. The question is whether another emergency meeting would add some benefit to the following players: — the US ambassador to the UN, the French UN diplomatic corps, the NGOs like Human Rights Watch, the myriad of security advisors/think tanks, PhD students, all who have a vested interest in raising the awareness of chemical weapon usage in Syria.

EU Set to Sanction Syria Scientists, Military Officers Over Chemical Attacks Norman (2107) July 16, states that: BRUSSELS—The European Union is set to target 16 Syrian scientists and military officers in a new round of sanctions against the Assad regime on Monday, seeking to punish those responsible for chemical weapons attacks against civilians. The move is a more limited version of a similar set of U.S. decisions earlier this year which targeted close to 300 people, including 271 employees of the Syria Scientific Studies and Research Centre. The EU measures will also hit scientists at the center, a Syrian government agency that Washington says is responsible for producing chemical and ballistic weapons, according to U.K. officials. The EU sanctions are set to be adopted on Monday at a meeting of the bloc’s foreign ministers. The exact list of targets won’t be known until the names are published Tuesday morning in the bloc’s official journal of record. However, U.K. Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson confirmed the decision Sunday night, saying the British government “will continue to work closely with our international partners to hold perpetrators to account.” The decision was confirmed by two other European sources. The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons last year said there were several cases of chlorine use as a chemical weapon by the regime of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad (para. 1-7). Norman, L. (2107). EU Set to Sanction Syria Scientists, Military Officers Over Chemical Attacks. The Wall Street Journal. World. Middle East. Middle East News. Retrieved from
https://www.wsj.com/articles/eu-set-to-sanction-syria-scientists-military-officers-over-chemical-attacks-1500244200

The Syrian regime has reportedly used chemical weapons against its own people in 2013 and again in April of this year (2017). A report from the OPCW is set to come out in October 2017 that will confirm the source of the chemical weapon attack in April 2017, though it is thought to be the Syrian regime. A UN Security Council emergency meeting was called in April 2017 in response to the chemical attack in Syria and Trump ordered the bombing of a Syrian air base. On July 27, 2017, President Trump put forth a warning to Syria that it would pay a heavy price if it used chemical weapons in response to an vague report from the Pentagon that chemical weapon preparations were underway at a Syrian air base. The US, Russia, and Jordan agreed to a ceasefire on July 9, 2017 with the purpose of deescalating aggressions. While Nikki Haley seems invested in preventing and punishing the use of chemical weapons by the Syrian regime, Trump and Secretary of State Tillerson seem complacent about the state of the regime.
A panel is currently investigating the matter ...  whether it will reach the level of the Security Council and survive Russia's veto is still an open question

Trump has been effective lately using teleprompter-better for him Masters, Tillerson and Mattis 
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-40413563
Crystal clear' warning - Jonathan Marcus, BBC defence and diplomatic correspondent
The very public warning to the Syrian government against using chemical weapons is highly unusual. Such a step , which must surely be based upon detailed intelligence, might usually be delivered behind the scenes through diplomatic channels.
The use of chemical weapons requires tell-tale preparations such as the movement of particular units, the distribution of weapons to a base from which they can be delivered and so on, all capable of being picked up by US satellites or drones.
The warning is clearly intended to forestall such an attack and to make it clear that if the Syrian regime again crosses this line - just as it did last April - the US will respond with force.
This time though the context is very different. There is growing friction between the US and pro-Assad forces. A US strike now would risk Washington being drawn further into the conflict. But the warning from the White House is crystal clear.

Sitting high on renewed prospect of attention to this matter. But UN didn't for prior chemical attack, and US, quite successfully, took unilateral action, so not likely for this one The White House statement and any action all relies heavily on perceived, rather than actual threat of chemical weapons, though and irregardless of whether he plans to imminently attack his own people again or not, adopting this stance gives US  some control over Syria, Russia and Iraq.

U.S. threatens Syria, says Assad is planning chemical weapons attack Mason and Walcott (2017) Tue Jun 27, states that: The White House warned Syrian President Bashar al-Assad on Monday that he and his military would "pay a heavy price" if it conducted a chemical weapons attack and said the United States had reason to believe such preparations were underway. The White House said in a statement released late on Monday the preparations by Syria were similar to those undertaken before an April 4 chemical attack that killed dozens of civilians and prompted U.S. President Donald Trump to order a cruise missile strike on a Syrian air base. "The United States has identified potential preparations for another chemical weapons attack by the Assad regime that would likely result in the mass murder of civilians, including innocent children," White House spokesman Sean Spicer said. "If ... Mr. Assad conducts another mass murder attack using chemical weapons, he and his military will pay a heavy price," he said (para 1-4). Assad said in an interview with the AFP news agency earlier this year that the alleged April attack was "100 percent fabrication" used to justify a U.S. air strike (para. 8). The strike was the toughest direct U.S. action yet in Syria's six-year-old civil war, raising the risk of confrontation with Russia and Iran, Assad's two main military backers. 'ABNORMAL ACTIVITY' U.S. and allied intelligence officers had for some time identified several sites where they suspected the Assad government may have been hiding newly made chemical weapons from inspectors, said one U.S. official familiar with the intelligence (para. 8-10). Mason, J. & Walcott, J. (2017). U.S. threatens Syria, says Assad is planning chemical weapons attack. Reuters. Top News. Retrieved from
http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-mideast-crisis-syria-usa-idUKKBN19I07K

If not yet, when?  Very unlikely.

Use of chemical weapons is likely to lead to an airstrike so it is not in Assad's best interest to use them at this time. If he does there will probably be a UN Security Council emergency meeting. More likely is ISIS using them and blaming it on Assad, that would also lead to an emergency meeting.

I don't think it is likely that Assad uses chemical weapons again this year. My impression of the attack back in April (American politics these days makes that feel like an eternity ago) was that Assad was testing what trump would do in response. Now that he knows, and since he is still winning, there's no need for him to use chemical weapons again.
Meetings are easy, even emergency ones.  Resolutions are impossible.  This Q is about a meeting, not a result.  Still not especially likely, but better odds than zero, I think.

Security Council Fails to Adopt Resolution Condemning Chemical Weapons Use in Syria, Following Veto by Russian Federation Representative Rejects ‘Sly Political Language’ against Damascus Government
The Security Council today rejected a draft resolution that would have condemned the reported chemical weapons attack on the Syrian town of Khan Shaykhun and expressed its determination to hold the perpetrators accountable. Defeated by 10 votes in favour, to 2 against (Bolivia, Russian Federation), with 3 abstentions (China, Ethiopia, Kazakhstan), the draft would have emphasized Syria’s obligation to comply with the recommendations of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapon’s (OPCW) Fact Finding Mission and the OPCW-United Nations Joint Investigative Mechanism by providing immediate and unfettered access to and the right to inspect any and all sites.  Tabled by France, the United Kingdom and the United States, it would have requested the Secretary-General to report on the issue every 30 days pursuant to resolution 2118 (2013), in which the Council had decided that, among other things, Syria would not use, develop, produce, acquire, stockpile or retain chemical weapons. Before the action, the Russian Federation’s delegate, saying the draft failed to serve a useful purpose, requested that an independent investigation be launched immediately on the incident in Khan Shaykhun. Following the vote, speakers agreed on the need for a swift, impartial investigation and for perpetrators to be held accountable for the reported chemical attacks.  Ethiopia’s speaker expressed regret over the disunity in the Council, emphasizing that Council members had agreed on the thrust of the text. Many speakers echoed that regret.  The Council’s inability to act had sent a message that perpetrators could “get away with murder”, said Ukraine’s delegate.  “Today, I feel ashamed.  This vote was a credibility test for the Council and we have not passed it.” The representative of the United States, whose country holds the Council presidency for April, said in her national capacity that the text had included information that was obvious:  that Bashar al-Assad’s regime must provide access to sites.  If the Assad regime was innocent, the information in the text would have vindicated it.  Having voted for the eighth time against a resolution on Syria, the Russian Federation was further isolating itself (para. 1-7). United Nations Security Council Website. (2017). Security Council Fails to Adopt Resolution Condemning Chemical Weapons Use in Syria, Following Veto by Russian Federation. 7922ND MEETING (PM). SC/12791.12 APRIL 2017. Retrieved from
https://www.un.org/press/en/2017/sc12791.doc.htm Stea, C. (2017). Syria: UN Mission Report Confirms that “Opposition” Rebels Used Chemical Weapons against Civilians and Government Forces. Global Research. Syria. Retrieved from
http://www.globalresearch.ca/syria-un-mission-report-confirms-that-opposition-rebels-used-chemical-weapons-against-civilians-and-government-forces/5363139 Madden, P., Meek, J., G., Christie, M. & Ross, B. (2017). United Nations to hold emergency meeting after suspected chemical attack in Syria. ABC News. 
http://abcnews.go.com/International/united-nations-hold-emergency-meeting-suspected-chemical-attack/story?id=46589159
Will be reducing probability by 1 percentage point per month

Putin came to Assad's defense in a recent interview, denying any Syrian use by the regime and accusing those who want to blame Assad for using them (http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-putin-syria-chemical-attack-20170602-story.html). With such support, Assad might feel embolden to use them again if it appears the rebels might gain a strategic advantage. Which would then result in an emergency meeting that will likely result in no action due to Russia's veto power. As for the US use of tomahawks, I would argue that the strike was neither strategic nor effective, instead simply attacking a military installation instead of addressing the larger strategic problem of Assad (and subsequently Russia's support of him).  15%, as I don't think it's very likely Assad will use the weapons again in the next few months, but changes on the battlefield may change his decision as to when and how to use them.

This can't happen without first being a second chemical attack. As far as I remember, Syria has only used chem. weapons twice since the civil war began. That's a 28% base rate, with Trump's 58 Tomahawk missiles attacking their base, I believe that's a particularly strong deterrent to doing so again.  Forecasting at work though so can and will adapt as necessary.
